page.title: 06Farming_sheep.
page.content: The primary occupation of the hill farmer is breeding and rearing sheep for the meat market.The flock,in summer,consists of between one hundred and fifty and two hundred animals, including the new lambs.To support such numbers,the poor upland soil has to be regularly fertilised and spread with manure.Generally,a farmer keeps his own rams_approximately six are maintained.Every so often he will sell an individual ram and introduce an outsider into the group so as to avoid inbreeding and its consequent diseases and disabilities.The ewes are covered in three groups during the months of October and November.This enables some lambs to be born in mid-March,some in mid-April and the rest in late April. By doing this all the lambing work does not fall at once.
